The existence of at least three types of opioid receptors (μ, δ, and κ) has been demonstrated(1Pasternak G.W. The Opiate Receptors. The Humana Press, Clifton, NJ1988Google Scholar). The μ opioid receptors mediate many effects of opiates and opioid compounds, including, most notably, modulation of pain perception(1Pasternak G.W. The Opiate Receptors. The Humana Press, Clifton, NJ1988Google Scholar). Activation of μ opioid receptors couples via pertussis toxin-sensitive G proteins to various effectors including adenylate cyclase and K+ and Ca2+ channels(1Pasternak G.W. The Opiate Receptors. The Humana Press, Clifton, NJ1988Google Scholar). Cloning of the μ opioid receptor has been reported recently by several laboratories(2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar, 3Fukuda K. Kato S. Mori K. Nishi M. Takeshima H. FEBS Lett. 1993; 327: 311-314Google Scholar, 4Wang J.B. Imai Y. Eppler C.M. Gregor P. Spivak C.S. Uhl G.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 10230-10234Google Scholar, 5Thompson R.C. Mansour A. Akil H. Watson S.J. Neuron. 1993; 11: 903-913Google Scholar, 6Bunzow J.R. Zhang G. Bouvier C. Saez C. Ronnekleiv O.K. Kelly M.J. Grandy D.K. J. Neurochem. 1995; 64: 14-24Google Scholar, 7Wang J.-B. Johnson P.S. Persico A.M. Hawkins A.L. Griffin C.A. Uhl G.R. FEBS Lett. 1994; 338: 217-222Google Scholar, 8Bare L.A. Mansson E. Yang D. FEBS Lett. 1994; 354: 213-216Google Scholar). Hydropathy analysis of deduced amino acid sequences of these clones indicates the presence of seven putative transmembrane helices (TMHs)1 1The abbreviations: TMHtransmembrane helixCHOChinese hamster ovarye3 loopthe third extracellular loopCHO-RMORCHO cell lines stably expressing the rat μ opioid receptorCOS-RMORCOS-1 cells transiently expressing the rat μ opioid receptorCTAPcyclic D-Phe-Cys-Tyr-D-Trp-Arg-Thr-Pen-Thr-NH2β-FNAβ-funaltrexaminei3 loopthe third intracellular loopPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisRMORthe rat μ opioid receptorRKORthe rat κ opioid receptorWGLwheat germ lectin. 1The abbreviations: TMHtransmembrane helixCHOChinese hamster ovarye3 loopthe third extracellular loopCHO-RMORCHO cell lines stably expressing the rat μ opioid receptorCOS-RMORCOS-1 cells transiently expressing the rat μ opioid receptorCTAPcyclic D-Phe-Cys-Tyr-D-Trp-Arg-Thr-Pen-Thr-NH2β-FNAβ-funaltrexaminei3 loopthe third intracellular loopPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisRMORthe rat μ opioid receptorRKORthe rat κ opioid receptorWGLwheat germ lectin. separated by intra- and extracellular loops, characteristics of G protein-coupled receptors. transmembrane helix Chinese hamster ovary the third extracellular loop CHO cell lines stably expressing the rat μ opioid receptor COS-1 cells transiently expressing the rat μ opioid receptor cyclic D-Phe-Cys-Tyr-D-Trp-Arg-Thr-Pen-Thr-NH2 β-funaltrexamine the third intracellular loop polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis the rat μ opioid receptor the rat κ opioid receptor wheat germ lectin. transmembrane helix Chinese hamster ovary the third extracellular loop CHO cell lines stably expressing the rat μ opioid receptor COS-1 cells transiently expressing the rat μ opioid receptor cyclic D-Phe-Cys-Tyr-D-Trp-Arg-Thr-Pen-Thr-NH2 β-funaltrexamine the third intracellular loop polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis the rat μ opioid receptor the rat κ opioid receptor wheat germ lectin. Affinity ligands that form covalent bonds with receptors have been very useful in the elucidation of receptor structure. Specific incorporation of radiolabeled affinity ligand into the receptor followed by SDS-PAGE and fluorography or autoradiography has been used to identify the receptor, to determine the molecular mass of the receptor without purification, and to examine the nature of carbohydrate moieties (see, for example, (9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar)). Because of the covalent nature of the bond between the ligand and the receptor, the site of incorporation, thus part of the binding domain, can be precisely determined by peptide mapping and/or determination of amino acid sequences of labeled fragments. For example, [3H]SKF 102,229 labeled adrenergic receptor α2 as a glycoprotein with a mass of 64 kDa(10Regan J.W. Raymond J.R. Lefkowitz R.J. DeMarinis R.M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1986; 137: 606-613Google Scholar). By peptide mapping of [3H]SKF 102,229 (antagonist)-labeled and [3H]azidoclonidine (agonist)-labeled α2-adrenergic receptors, Matsui et al.(11Matsui H. Lefkowitz R.J. Caron M.G. Regan J.W. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 4125-4130Google Scholar) identified the fourth TMH to be the region that formed covalent bonds with these ligands and, thus, to be part of the binding domain. β-Funaltrexamine (β-FNA), synthesized by Portoghese et al.(12Portoghese P.S. Larson D.L. Sayre L.M. Fries D.S. Takemori A.E. J. Med. Chem. 1980; 23: 233-234Google Scholar), was shown to have reversible κ agonist and irreversible μ antagonist activities (for a review, see (13Takemori A.E. Portoghese P.S. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1985; 25: 193-223Google Scholar)). The high selectivity and irreversible nature of its action on μ opioid receptors makes β-FNA a very useful pharmacological tool both in vivo and in vitro. Binding of β-FNA to opioid receptors in tissue membrane preparations in vitro has also been characterized(14Tam S.W. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1986; 239: 351-357Google Scholar, 15Recht L.D. Pasternak G.W. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1987; 140: 209-214Google Scholar, 16Rothman R.B. Long J.B. Bykov V. Jacobson A.E. Rice K.C. Holaday J.W. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1988; 247: 405-416Google Scholar, 17Franklin T.G. Traynor J.R. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1991; 102: 718-722Google Scholar). β-FNA binds to μ, κ, and δ receptors with IC50 values of 2.2, 14, and 78 nM, respectively(14Tam S.W. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1986; 239: 351-357Google Scholar). There is a general agreement that β-FNA binds reversibly, and not irreversibly, to κ opioid receptors. β-FNA binds irreversibly to μ opioid receptors (14Tam S.W. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1986; 239: 351-357Google Scholar, 15Recht L.D. Pasternak G.W. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1987; 140: 209-214Google Scholar) and at low concentrations (1-10 nM) [3H]β-FNA covalently labels only μ opioid binding sites with high specificity(18Liu-Chen L.-Y. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1987; 32: 321-329Google Scholar, 19Liu-Chen L.-Y. Li S. Tallarida R.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1990; 37: 243-251Google Scholar, 20Liu-Chen L.-Y. Li S. Lewis M.E. Brain Res. 1991; 544: 235-242Google Scholar). In addition, at concentrations≥18 nM, β-FNA also binds irreversibly to δ receptors(14Tam S.W. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1986; 239: 351-357Google Scholar). [3H]β-FNA-labeled μ opioid receptors in the rat brain have broad molecular mass ranges from 60-75 kDa (median: 67 kDa)(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar), indicative of glycoprotein nature. Upon deglycosylation by N-glycanase®, labeled rat μ receptors became a sharp band of 39 kDa(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar). Chimeric receptors of closely related receptors have been very useful in the delineation of ligand binding domains of receptors. By examining the binding characteristics of μ/κ chimeric receptors, we (21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar) and Wang et al.(22Wang J.B. Johnson P.S. Wu J.M. Wang W.F. Uhl G.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25966-25969Google Scholar) demonstrated that the second extracellular loop of the κ receptor was essential for the high affinity binding of dynorphin family peptides. In addition, we found that the TMHs 6 and 7 and the third extracellular (e3) loop of the κ receptor was critical for the binding of the selective antagonist norbinaltorphimine(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). Moreover, we demonstrated that the TMHs 6 and 7 and the e3 loop of the μ receptor is important for binding of selective agonists(23Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 12977-12979Google Scholar). Kong et al.(24Kong H. Raynor K. Yano H. Takeda J. Bell G.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 8042-8046Google Scholar) examined the binding characteristics of δ/κ chimeric receptors and found that the binding domain of κ selective antagonists was located in the N-terminal domain. Onogi et al.(25Onogi T. Minami M. Katao Y. Nakagawa T. Aoki Y. Toya T. Katsumata S. Satoh M. FEBS Lett. 1995; 357: 93-97Google Scholar) reported that the determinant of selectivity of the μ receptor for Tyr-D-Ala-Gly-NMePhe-Gly-ol was located in the first extracellular loop, based on analysis of binding of [3H]Tyr-D-Ala-Gly-NMePhe-Gly-ol to a series of chimeric μ/δ opioid receptors β-FNA has been shown to bind irreversibly to both μ1 and μ2 receptors in brain membranes(15Recht L.D. Pasternak G.W. Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1987; 140: 209-214Google Scholar). Recent cloning of the μ opioid receptor makes it possible to study the interaction of β-FNA with one single type of μ receptors at the molecular level. In this study, we examined the binding of [3H]β-FNA to the cloned rat μ opioid receptor (RMOR) (2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar), as compared to native receptors in the rat brain. In addition, we also determined the region in the μ receptor that conferred selectivity for covalent binding of β-FNA. For this purpose, we examined binding of β-FNA to chimeric μ/κ receptors constructed from cloned rat μ and κ opioid receptors(2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar, 26Li S. Zhu J. Chen C. Chen Y.-W. de Riel J.K. Ashby B. Liu-Chen L.-Y. Biochem. J. 1993; 295: 629-633Google Scholar), since the RMOR does, yet the rat κ receptor (RKOR) does not, form a covalent bond with [3H]β-FNA. Rat μ and κ receptors and chimeras were transfected into COS-1 cells with DEAE-dextran-chloroquine method and membranes of COS cells transfected with RMOR (COS-RMOR) were prepared for binding as described(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar, 26Li S. Zhu J. Chen C. Chen Y.-W. de Riel J.K. Ashby B. Liu-Chen L.-Y. Biochem. J. 1993; 295: 629-633Google Scholar). RMOR is in the vector pRc/CMV, which contains a neomycin-resistant gene. Transfection of CHO cells with RMOR was performed with 30 μl of Lipofectin® (1 mg/ml) and 10 μg of DNA/100-mm dish according to Felgner et al.(27Felgner P.L. Gadek T.R. Holm M. Roman R. Chan H.W. Wenz M. Northrop J.P. Ringold G.M. Danielsen M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 7413-7417Google Scholar). After transfection and 48-60 h in the growth medium, cells were subcultured at the ratio of 1:5 into the growth medium containing Geneticin (0.5 mg/ml) for 4 weeks for selection of cells expressing the neomycin-resistant gene. Clonal cells were grown in 24-well plates, and [3H]diprenorphine binding was performed on cells adhering to wells(28Toll L. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1992; 260: 9-15Google Scholar). CHO cells expressing the rat μ opioid receptor (CHO-RMOR) were maintained in medium containing Geneticin (0.2 mg/ml) and membranes prepared for binding(26Li S. Zhu J. Chen C. Chen Y.-W. de Riel J.K. Ashby B. Liu-Chen L.-Y. Biochem. J. 1993; 295: 629-633Google Scholar). Brain membranes of Sprague-Dawley rats were prepared as described(18Liu-Chen L.-Y. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1987; 32: 321-329Google Scholar). Binding experiments were performed in the presence of 100 mM NaCl with [3H]diprenorphine at a concentration close to its Kd for each receptor and 9 concentrations of β-FNA at room temperature for 60 min as described previously(26Li S. Zhu J. Chen C. Chen Y.-W. de Riel J.K. Ashby B. Liu-Chen L.-Y. Biochem. J. 1993; 295: 629-633Google Scholar). Membranes suspended in 50 mM TEL buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl buffer, 1 mM EGTA, 10 μM leupeptin) were incubated with [3H]β-FNA at specified concentrations in the presence of indicated concentrations of NaCl at 37°C for specified periods of time. Each assay tube contained 20-50 μg of membrane proteins. Nonspecific labeling was performed in the presence of 10 μM naloxone. Selective drugs were added at various concentrations for characterization on inhibition of irreversible binding. Irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA in labeled membranes was assayed according to our published method(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar, 19Liu-Chen L.-Y. Li S. Tallarida R.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1990; 37: 243-251Google Scholar). Labeled membranes were precipitated with trichloroacetic acid, filtered over GF/B filters, and radioactivity on the filter determined. Both solubilization and WGL affinity chromatography were carried at 4°C according to our published procedure(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar). Solubilization was carried out with 2% Nonidet P-40 instead of 2% Triton X-100. N-Glycanase treatment was conducted as described previously(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar). SDS-PAGE and fluorography was performed as described previously (9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar) with 14C-labeled protein molecular mass standards. Four chimeric μ/κ receptors (III, IV, XI, and XII) constructed in the vector pcDNA3 or pBK-CMV from RMOR and RKOR were used in this study. Chimera III (amino acids κ1-141/μ151-398) and chimera IV (amino acids μ1-150/κ142-380) were constructed by swapping the regions from the N terminus to the start of the TMH 3. Chimera XI (amino acids μ1-268/κ263-380) and chimera XII (amino acids κ1-262/μ269-398) were generated by exchanging the regions from the middle of the third intracellular (i3) loop to the C terminus. Details of generation of these chimeras were described previously(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). Protein contents of membranes and solubilized preparations were determined by the BCA method of Smith et al.(29Smith P.K. Krohn R.I. Hermanson G.T. Mallia A.K. Gartner F.H. Provenzano M.D. Fujimoto E.K. Goeke N.M. Olson B.J. Klenk D.C. Anal. Biochem. 1985; 150: 76-85Google Scholar) with bovine serum albumin as the standard. [3H]β-FNA (15.6 Ci/mmol) was supplied by National Institute on Drug Abuse. [3H]diprenorphine (35 Ci/mmol) was purchased from Amersham Corp. Naloxone and U50,488H were generously provided by DuPont Merck Pharmaceutical Co. and Upjohn, respectively. CTAP and ICI174,584 were purchased from Chiron Co. (San Diego, CA). WGL-Sepharose 6MB and DEAE-dextran were obtained from Pharmacia Biotech Inc.; peptide-N4[N-acetyl-β-glucosaminyl]asparagine amidase (EC 3.5.1.52) (from Flavobacterium meningosepticum) (N-glycanase®) from Genzyme Co. (Boston, MA); Lipofectin® reagent and 14C-labeled standards from Life Technologies, Inc. β-FNA inhibited 0.4 nM [3H]diprenorphine binding to the μ receptor expressed in COS-1 cells with high affinity. The IC50 value was calculated to be 1.7 ± 0.2 nM (n = 3) after a 60-min incubation at 25°C. Membranes of COS-RMOR cells were incubated with 4 nM [3H]β-FNA in the presence of 100 mM NaCl at 37°C for various periods of time. The nonspecific binding increased very slowly with time, whereas the specific irreversible binding increased rapidly with time and approached a plateau at 100-120 min (Fig. 1). Membranes of COS-RMOR cells were incubated in the presence of 100 mM NaCl at 37°C for 75 min with various concentrations of [3H]β-FNA. While the nonspecific binding increased with [3H]β-FNA concentration, the specific irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA reached a plateau at 3 nM (Fig. 4, RMOR). Untransfected COS-1 or CHO cells showed no specific irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA. NaCl greatly enhanced the specific irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA to the μ opioid receptor with the maximal effect at 200 mM. When compared to the level of specific binding in the presence of 100 mM NaCl (designated as 100%), those in the presence of various NaCl concentrations were as follows: no NaCl, 35.1%; 50 mM, 81.4%; 200 mM, 113.8%; 300 mM, 110.6% (mean of two experiments). Specific irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA to RMOR expressed in COS-1 cells was potently inhibited by CTAP (a selective μ ligand), but not by U50,488H (a κ ligand) and ICI174,864 (a δ ligand). The IC50 of CTAP was approximately 70 nM. It should be noted that the IC50 value of CTAP, a reversible ligand, in inhibiting the irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA does not represent its true affinity. In contrast, neither ICI174,864 nor U50,488H at 10 μM inhibited [3H]β-FNA irreversible binding at all. As shown in Fig. 2, [3H]β-FNA specifically labeled one band with a mass of 70-89 kDa (median: 80 kDa) in WGL-purified COS-RMOR preparation, one band with mass of 70-89 kDa (median: 80 kDa) in CHO-RMOR membranes, and one band with mass of 61-78 kDa (median: 67 kDa) in the WGL-purified rat brain preparation. Naloxone inhibited the labeling of the 80-kDa protein bands. We have shown previously that in the WGL-purified rat brain preparation, there is only one labeled band of 67 kDa, of which labeling is greatly reduced by naloxone(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar). All these three bands were broad and diffuse, indicating that labeled receptors are glycoproteins. Membranes of COS-1 cells transfected with the vector pcDNA3 alone did not show any labeled protein band (not shown). After deglycosylation with N-glycanase™174; to remove Asn-linked carbohydrates, both the 80-kDa protein band in the CHO-RMOR membranes and the 67-kDa band in the rat brain preparation became sharp bands of ~40 kDa (Fig. 3). These results indicate that the difference in the molecular mass of cloned receptors and native receptors reflects differences in the extent of glycosylation. We have previously shown that chimeras III, IV, XI, and XII bound [3H]diprenorphine with high affinity, with Kd values of 0.30, 0.78, 0.49, and 0.14 nM, respectively(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). These values are similar to Kd values of μ and κ receptors (0.35 and 0.26 nM, respectively)(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). β-FNA inhibited [3H]diprenorphine binding to all four chimeras with high affinity with IC50 values of 1.7, 12.5, 3.0, 13.8, 5.5, and 3.5 nM for μ, κ, III, IV, XI, and XII respectively (Table 1).TABLE I Open table in a new tab Irreversible binding of a range of concentrations of [3H]β-FNA was carried out (Fig. 4). [3H]β-FNA bound irreversibly to RMOR, but not RKOR. While chimeras III showed high [3H]β-FNA specific irreversible binding, similar to RMOR, [3H]β-FNA did not bind irreversibly to chimeras IV (Fig. 4). Thus, the region from the TMH 3 to the C terminus of the μ receptor is necessary for irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA. To further narrow down the region, we examined irreversible binding to chimeras XI and XII. XII, constructed by substitution of the portion from the middle of i3 loop to the C terminus of RKOR with that of RMOR, acquired high [3H]β-FNA specific irreversible binding, similar to RMOR (Fig. 4). On the other hand, XI, constructed by replacement of the portion from the middle of i3 loop to the C terminus of RMOR with that of RKOR, did not display any [3H]β-FNA specific irreversible binding (Fig. 4). These results indicate that the region from the middle of the i3 loop to the C terminus is essential for irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA. Chimeras IV and XI were expressed at lower levels in COS-1 cells than RKOR, RMOR, chimeras III and XII, in terms of fmol/mg of membrane protein(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). In experiments shown in Fig. 4, receptor concentrations were adjusted to similar levels for all receptors (50-60 fmol/ml/tube). Therefore, the amount of protein in the assay was different among these receptors, which accounted for different levels of nonspecific binding of each receptor. Expression levels of a given receptor from different transfection experiments were remarkably similar(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). Thus, the variations between experiments were small. In this study, we demonstrated that the cloned rat μ opioid receptor bound β-FNA with a high affinity and could be specifically and irreversibly labeled by [3H]β-FNA under defined conditions. [3H]β-FNA-labeled receptors in COS-1 or CHO cells appeared as one diffuse broad band of 80 kDa, as compared to 67 kDa of the μ receptor in the rat brain. Upon deglycosylation, labeled receptors became much sharper bands with similar Mr values of ~40 kDa. By examining irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA to four chimeric μ/κ receptors, we demonstrated that the portion from the middle of the i3 loop to the C terminus of the μ receptor was important for covalent binding of [3H]β-FNA. At 37°C, the irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA to the cloned μ receptor was time- and [3H]β-FNA concentration-dependent, reaching a plateau at 3 nM and 100-120 min. The presence of Na+ was essential for high level of [3H]β-FNA irreversible binding to the μ receptor. CTAP potently inhibited irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA, whereas ICI174,584 and U50,488H did not. These results are consistent with our previous observation that [3H]β-FNA binds irreversibly to the μ receptor in brain membranes(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar, 18Liu-Chen L.-Y. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1987; 32: 321-329Google Scholar, 19Liu-Chen L.-Y. Li S. Tallarida R.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1990; 37: 243-251Google Scholar, 20Liu-Chen L.-Y. Li S. Lewis M.E. Brain Res. 1991; 544: 235-242Google Scholar). It has been thought that β-FNA reacts with a Cys residue in the vicinity of the binding site of μ receptors to form a covalent bond(12Portoghese P.S. Larson D.L. Sayre L.M. Fries D.S. Takemori A.E. J. Med. Chem. 1980; 23: 233-234Google Scholar, 14Tam S.W. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1986; 239: 351-357Google Scholar). The μ receptors in brain membranes contain the complex type of carbohydrates linked to the Asn residue of the receptor(9Liu-Chen L.-Y. Chen C. Phillips C.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 749-756Google Scholar). The cloned rat μ receptor contains five consensus Asn-linked glycosylation sites (2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar). Whether each Asn residue is glycosylated remains to be determined. The carbohydrate moiety comprises a high percentage of the μ receptor molecular mass. The exact function of the carbohydrate moiety is not known. Native μ receptors and cloned μ receptors expressed in COS-1 or CHO cells, although displaying different extents of glycosylation, exhibited very similar binding and signal transduction properties(2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar). These observations indicate that carbohydrate moieties are not important in binding or signal transduction. Similar conclusions were reached by Pasternak et al.(30Pasternak G.W. Snyder S.H. Mol. Pharmacol. 1974; 10: 183-193Google Scholar) and Law et al.(31Law P.-Y. Ungar H.G. Hom D.S. Loh H.H. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985; 34: 9-17Google Scholar). Neuraminidase treatment did not affect opioid receptor binding (30Pasternak G.W. Snyder S.H. Mol. Pharmacol. 1974; 10: 183-193Google Scholar). Law et al.(31Law P.-Y. Ungar H.G. Hom D.S. Loh H.H. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1985; 34: 9-17Google Scholar) found that glycosylation plays an important role in the structural maturation and insertion into plasma membranes of δ opioid receptors in NG108-15 cells, but not for ligand binding or activation of the second messenger system. To our knowledge, no similar study on the μ receptor has been performed. Deglycosylated μ receptors have a molecular mass of ~40 kDa, which is smaller than the molecular mass of 44 kDa predicted from the deduced amino acid sequence(2Chen Y. Mestek A. Liu J. Hurley J.A. Yu L. Mol. Pharmacol. 1993; 44: 8-12Google Scholar). The reason for this discrepancy is not clear. There may be other post-translational modifications of μ opioid receptor proteins, such as phosphorylation, palmitoylation, or isoprenylation, which affect mobility of labeled receptors in SDS-PAGE. Another possibility that cannot be entirely ruled out is that a part of the receptor molecule is particularly susceptible to protease activities. This part may be removed during the process of [3H]β-FNA labeling (37°C, 75 min) and/or N-glycanase® treatment (37°C, 6 h), even though protease inhibitors were present during these processes. Irreversible binding of [3H]β-FNA to chimeric μ/κ receptors was examined to define the structural basis of μ selectivity of β-FNA irreversible binding. All four chimeras bound [3H]diprenorphine with high affinity, similar to μ and κ receptors(21Xue J.-C. Chen C. Zhu J. Kunapuli S. de Riel J.K. Yu L. Liu-Chen L.-Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30195-30199Google Scholar). Binding of [3H]diprenorphine to all chimeras was completely blocked by naloxone. These results indicate that these chimeras retain opioid receptor conformation to some extent. All four chimeras bound β-FNA with similar high affinities as μ andκ receptors, yet [3H]β-FNA bound irreversibly to chimeras III and XII, but not IV and XI. Thus, the inability of chimeras IV and XI and the κ receptors to bind β-FNA irreversibly is not due to their inability to bind β-FNA reversibly. These findings indicate that the region from the third i3 loop to the C terminus is necessary for covalent binding of [3H]β-FNA. Two possibilities may exist. First, the site of β-FNA covalent incorporation is within the region from the i3 loop to the C terminus. Amino acid sequences within the i3 loop, most of TMH 6 and TMH 7 are very similar between μ and κ receptors. The C-terminal domain of the μ receptor does not contribute to ligand binding(32Surratt C.K. Johnson P.S. Moriwaki A. Seidleck B.K. Blaschak C.J. Wang J.B. Uhl G.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20548-20553Google Scholar). Thus, the sequence in and around the e3 loop of the μ receptor appears to confer selectivity for β-FNA irreversible binding. Second, chimeras III and XII assume favorable conformations for β-FNA to form covalent bonds with the receptors, whereas chimeras IV and XI do not. Preservation of opioid receptor conformation of the chimeras was confirmed by high affinity binding of diprenorphine, naloxone, and β-FNA. However, the possibilities cannot be excluded that there are potential local conformational changes in the binding pocket, or that there are alterations in direct interactions between the receptor and the ligand(33Ackers G.K. Smith F.R. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1985; 54: 597-629Google Scholar). We are currently conducting peptide mapping analysis of [3H]β-FNA-labeled receptor to determine the region of [3H]β-FNA incorporation. In conclusion, the cloned rat μ opioid receptor expressed in COS-1 or CHO cells could be specifically and covalently labeled by [3H]β-FNA. The labeled receptor appeared as one diffuse broad band of 80 kDa by SDS-PAGE and fluorography and upon deglycosylation, it became a sharp band of ~40 kDa. The region between the middle of the i3 loop to the C terminus in the μ receptor is necessary for covalent bond formation with [3H]β-FNA. We will determine the region and eventually the amino acid residue that forms covalent bond with [3H]β-FNA. Since [3H]β-FNA is a rigid molecule, the information will be very useful for computerized modeling of the μ receptor.

To investigate the degree of conservation of the cell cycle-specific NIMA protein kinase of Aspergillus nidulans, and to help direct its functional analysis, we cloned a homolog (designated nim-1) from Neurospora crassa. Over the catalytic domain NIM-1 is 75% identical to NIMA, but overall the identity drops to 52%. nim-1 was able to functionally complement nimA5 in A. nidulans. Mutational analysis of potential activating phosphorylation sites found in NIMA, NIM-1, and related protein kinases was performed on NIMA. Mutation of threonine 199 (conserved in all NIMA-related kinases) inhibited NIMA β-casein kinase activity and abolished its in vivo function. This site conforms to a minimal consensus phosphorylation site for NIMA (FXXT) and is analogous to the autophosphorylation site of cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinases. However, mutation of a unique cysteine residue found only in the catalytic site of NIMA and NIM-1 had no effect on NIMA kinase activity or function. Three temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA that cause arrest in G2 were sequenced and shown to generate three different amino acid substitutions. None of the mutations prevented accumulation of NIMA protein during G2 arrest, but all prevented the p34cdc2/cyclin B-dependent phosphorylation of NIMA normally seen during mitotic initiation even though p34cdc2/cyclin B H1 kinase activity was fully activated. To investigate the degree of conservation of the cell cycle-specific NIMA protein kinase of Aspergillus nidulans, and to help direct its functional analysis, we cloned a homolog (designated nim-1) from Neurospora crassa. Over the catalytic domain NIM-1 is 75% identical to NIMA, but overall the identity drops to 52%. nim-1 was able to functionally complement nimA5 in A. nidulans. Mutational analysis of potential activating phosphorylation sites found in NIMA, NIM-1, and related protein kinases was performed on NIMA. Mutation of threonine 199 (conserved in all NIMA-related kinases) inhibited NIMA β-casein kinase activity and abolished its in vivo function. This site conforms to a minimal consensus phosphorylation site for NIMA (FXXT) and is analogous to the autophosphorylation site of cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinases. However, mutation of a unique cysteine residue found only in the catalytic site of NIMA and NIM-1 had no effect on NIMA kinase activity or function. Three temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA that cause arrest in G2 were sequenced and shown to generate three different amino acid substitutions. None of the mutations prevented accumulation of NIMA protein during G2 arrest, but all prevented the p34cdc2/cyclin B-dependent phosphorylation of NIMA normally seen during mitotic initiation even though p34cdc2/cyclin B H1 kinase activity was fully activated. Initiation and exit from mitosis in Aspergillus nidulans requires the activation and inactivation of two cell cycle-regulated protein kinases, both of which have maximal kinase activity during mitotic initiation and also require mitotic transition to down-regulate their elevated mitotic activities (27Osmani A.H. McGuire S.L. Osmani S.A. Cell. 1991; 67: 283-291Google Scholar, 28Osmani A.H. O'Donnell K. Pu R.T. Osmani S.A. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 2669-2679Google Scholar, 29Osmani A.H. van Peij N. Mischke M. O'Connell M.J. Osmani S.A. J. Cell Sci. 1994; 107: 1519-1528Google Scholar, 32Osmani S.A. Pu R.T. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 53: 237-244Google Scholar; 42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar; 42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). One, the p34cdc2/cyclin B histone H1 kinase, is a universal regulator of mitosis in organisms ranging from fungi to humans, and much is known about its regulation through the cell cycle (7Draetta G. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1990; 15: 378-383Google Scholar; 21Nurse P. Nature. 1990; 344: 503-508Google Scholar; 20Norbury C. Nurse P. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 441-470Google Scholar). The second kinase, called NIMA, has at present only been identified as a key component of mitotic regulation in A. nidulans (5Doonan J.H. J. Cell Sci. 1992; 103: 599-611Google Scholar). However, expression of A. nidulans nimA in fission yeast, Xenopus, and human cell lines (24O'Connell M.J. Norbury C. Nurse P. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 4926-4937Google Scholar; 15Lu K.P. Hunter T. Cell. 1995; 81: 413-424Google Scholar) can induce mitotic events in these systems, and expression of a dominant negative version of nimA leads to an arrest of human cells in G2 (15Lu K.P. Hunter T. Cell. 1995; 81: 413-424Google Scholar). These data strongly indicate that NIMA is a universal component of cell cycle regulation, but until the current work no functional homolog had been identified. Temperature-sensitive mutations of nimA reversibly arrest cells in late G2 (22Oakley B.R. Morris N.R. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 96: 1155-1158Google Scholar). At the G2 arrest point of nimA5 cells contain a stable interphase microtubule array and show no signs of chromatin condensation or spindle formation, as determined using either indirect immunofluorescence or electron microscopy (19Morris N.R. Genet. Res. 1976; 26: 237-254Google Scholar; 22Oakley B.R. Morris N.R. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 96: 1155-1158Google Scholar; 2Bergen L.G. Upshall A. Morris N.R. J. Bacteriol. 1984; 159: 114-119Google Scholar; 30Osmani S.A. May G.S. Morris N.R. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 104: 1495-1504Google Scholar). Surprisingly, however, such arrested cells have activated p34cdc2 H1 kinase activity even though they are clearly arrested in G2 (27Osmani A.H. McGuire S.L. Osmani S.A. Cell. 1991; 67: 283-291Google Scholar). This suggests that NIMA could function either downstream or in parallel to p34cdc2 in order to promote mitosis. Evidence has recently accumulated suggesting that NIMA is activated and phosphorylated by p34cdc2/cyclin B during mitotic initiation (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). The phosphorylation of NIMA by p34cdc2/cyclin B is not required for a basal level of NIMA kinase activity but is required for the final mitotic activation of NIMA kinase. This interaction may play a role in coordinating the mitotic promoting activities of these two protein kinases (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). NIMA protein also accumulates during G2, as does its kinase activity, but it is then inactivated during mitosis by proteolysis (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). The degradation of mitotic NIMA is required for cells to exit from mitosis (34Pu R.T. Osmani S.A. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 995-1003Google Scholar). Several genes that encode protein kinases with significant similarity (>40% identity over the catalytic domain) to A. nidulans NIMA have been isolated from higher eukaryotes. These putative kinases have been termed nek for nimA related kinases or nrk, also for nimA related kinase, due to their protein sequence similarity to A. nidulans NIMA (13Letwin K. Mizzen L. Motro B. Ben-David Y. Bernstein A. Pawson T. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 3521-3531Google Scholar; 37Schultz S.J. Nigg E.A. Cell Growth & Differ. 1993; 4: 821-830Google Scholar; 14Levedakou E.N. He M. Baptist E.W. Craven R.J. Cance W.G. Welcsh P.L. Simmons A. Naylor S.L. Leach R.J. Lewis T.B. Bowcock A. Liu E.T. Oncogene. 1994; 9: 1977-1988Google Scholar; 38Schultz S.J. Fry A.M. Sutterlin C. Ried T. Nigg E.A. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 1-11Google Scholar). A nimA-like gene has also been isolated from yeast (11Jones D.G.L. Rosamond J. Gene (Amst.). 1990; 90: 87-92Google Scholar; 1Barton A. Davies C. Hutchison III, C. Kaback D. Gene (Amst.). 1992; 117: 137-140Google Scholar; 39Schweitzer B. Philippsen P. Mol. & Gen. Genet. 1992; 234: 164-167Google Scholar), and two related genes have been isolated from Trypanosome (8Gale Jr., M. Parsons M. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1993; 59: 111-122Google Scholar). The role of the NIMA-related kinases in cell cycle regulation remains to be established, but mouse nek1 is highly expressed in germ line cells, suggesting a role in meiosis (13Letwin K. Mizzen L. Motro B. Ben-David Y. Bernstein A. Pawson T. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 3521-3531Google Scholar). In addition, the level of human Nek2 protein is regulated through the cell cycle, reaching a maximum during G2, which indicates that Nek2 may play a cell cycle-specific role in humans (38Schultz S.J. Fry A.M. Sutterlin C. Ried T. Nigg E.A. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 1-11Google Scholar). The cell cycle variation in Nek2 protein level is similar to the fluctuations seen for NIMA protein during the cell cycle of A. nidulans (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar; 42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). To help identify important functional features of NIMA and to determine the existence of functional homologs, a nimA-like gene from Neurospora crassa was isolated. We have carried out functional analysis of this gene and also defined important amino acid residues required for NIMA function by mutagenesis and sequencing of previously isolated temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA. Aspergillus strains used were R153 (wA3; pyroA4), SO6 (nimA5; wA2; pyrG89; cnxE16; choA1; yA2; chaA1), and SO23 (nimA1; wA2; nicB8 or A2; choA1). Growth conditions, media, and transformation were as described previously (19Morris N.R. Genet. Res. 1976; 26: 237-254Google Scholar; 30Osmani S.A. May G.S. Morris N.R. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 104: 1495-1504Google Scholar, 31Osmani S.A. Engle D.B. Doonan J.H. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 52: 241-251Google Scholar). N. crassa genomic and cDNA libraries (25Orbach M.J. Porro E.B. Yanofsky C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 2452-2461Google Scholar, 26Orbach M.J. Sachs M.S. Yanofsky C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10981-10987Google Scholar) were obtained from the Fungal Genetic Stock Center (University of Kansas Medical Center). Restriction enzymes were obtained from Promega (Madison, WI), and T4 DNA ligase was purchased from New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA). Universal primers for M13 mp18 and M13 mp19 and specific primers for N. crassa nim-1 were used for sequencing (36Sanger F. Nicklen S. Coulson A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 5463-5467Google Scholar) using Sequenase obtained from U.S. Biochemical Corp. To generate overlapping clones for sequencing, nested deletion was performed using Cyclone I Biosystem from IBI (New Haven, CT). For nimA mutant allele sequencing, two overlapping polymerase chain reaction fragments were amplified using genomic DNA as template isolated from wild type and the three nimA mutant strains. A 5’ polymerase chain reaction primer pair (5’-ACAATGGCAATCGCACTGGCG-3’ forward primer and 5’-GGCTACACGATCCTGAACCTCGCA-3’ reverse primer) and a 3’ polymerase chain reaction primer pair (5’-GGTAAAGGCAAGATTAGAGATCGAT-3’ forward primer and 5’-AAAGATGCAGCAGCGCAAGAAATG-3’ reverse primer) were used to amplify the overlapping fragments (5’ fragment = 1269 base pairs, 3’ fragment = 1297 base pairs). After 35-40 cycles of denaturing (94°C, 35 s), annealing (65°C, 55 s), and extension (72°C, 2 min), the double stranded DNA templates were purified with GeneClean II (Bio 101, La Jolla, CA) and sequenced completely on both stands with the Applied Biosystems (Foster City, CA) Taq Dyedeoxy terminator cycle sequencing kit, using a series of oligonucleotide primers. Sequencing reactions were purified by G50 Sephadex gel filtration equilibrated in deionized H2O and run on an Applied Biosystems 373A sequencer. For Southern blot analysis genomic DNAs were isolated and restricted by KpnI followed by electrophoresis and standard Southern blot procedures. Blots were probed with a 2.0-kb1 1The abbreviations used are: kbkilobase(s)PAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. PstI nimA fragment or a 2.4-kb nim-1 fragment labeled to equal specific activity. DNA sequence analysis and alignment were performed using GCG software (University of Wisconsin) and PC-Gene software (Intelligenetics Inc). In vitro mutagenesis was performed on plasmid pET21a-NIMA (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar) using a site-directed mutagenesis kit from Clontech (Palo Alto, CA). After mutagenesis a BamHI fragment containing the mutation was used to replace the corresponding BamHI fragment of plasmid pAL5B (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). Primers used were as follows: S198A, 5’-CACGACTTTGCGGCCACCTATGT-3’; T199A, 5’-ACTTTGCGTCCGCCTATGTCGGAACAC-3’; Y200A, 5’-GCGTCCACCGCTGTCGGAACACC-3’; and Y203A, 5’-CCACCTATGTCGGAGCACCATTCTACA-3’. For each mutagenesis the selection primer was 5’-AACAATTCCCCTCGAGAAATAATTTTG-3’, which destroys an XbaI site in pET21a-NIMA. kilobase(s) polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Protein kinase assays and Western blot analysis were carried out as described previously (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). pUCX7 contains a 3.2-kb XbaI genomic fragment of nim-1 cloned into the XbaI site of pUC18. To generate pUCX7-4, a 0.6-kb HindIII fragment from pUCX7-17 was removed before religation. Plasmid pUCX7-27 was generated by inserting the 2.4-kb HindIII genomic fragment from pUC7-17 into pUCX7-4 in the reverse orientation. An N. crassa λ J1 genomic DNA library (25Orbach M.J. Porro E.B. Yanofsky C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 2452-2461Google Scholar) was probed with nimA cDNA under low stringency conditions. DNA was isolated from purified clones, and the hybridizing restriction fragments were cloned into both M13 and pUC18. We attempted to isolate a full-length cDNA from two different cDNA libraries (26Orbach M.J. Sachs M.S. Yanofsky C. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10981-10987Google Scholar) but were unable to isolate a full-length cDNA. The longest cDNA isolated and the genomic clones were sequenced on both strands as depicted in Fig. 1a. Hypothetical translation identified a long open reading frame (Fig. 2) encoding a protein with high similarity to A. nidulans NIMA (32Osmani S.A. Pu R.T. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 53: 237-244Google Scholar) (Fig. 3). The open reading frame was initiated from a methionine codon in a good context to initiate translation and was preceded closely by stop codons in each reading frame (underlined in Fig. 2). To maintain the open reading frame we propose the presence of two introns as indicated in Fig. 2, the first being 107 and the second 52 bases in length. Both putative introns contained consensus splice sites, and one is positioned in exactly the same location as one of the two introns present in A. nidulans nimA (see below). We propose to call this locus nim-1 and designate the translation product NIM-1. By Northern blot analysis nim-1 mRNA was estimated to be 3.0 kb in length (data not shown).Figure 3:Kinase domain alignment of NIMA protein kinase family. The kinase domains of NIMA, NIM-1, Kin3, Nek1, Nek2, Stk2, and NrkA were aligned using GCG software. Positions with more than half-identical residues are shaded. The 11-kinase subdomains are marked with Roman numerals below the sequences. Kinase signature residues are indicated above the aligned sequences as are the amino acid substitutions of the three nimA mutant alleles, which are marked in lowercase.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) NIM-1 contains 779 amino acids with a molecular weight of 86,056 and a pI of 10.8, similar to the values for NIMA (32Osmani S.A. Pu R.T. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 53: 237-244Google Scholar). Alignment of NIM-1 to NIMA shows both to contain the conserved features of protein kinases in their N termini (10Hanks S.K. Quinn A.M. Hunter T. Science. 1988; 241: 42-52Google Scholar). Over the catalytic domain of 295 amino acids they have 75% identical residues, and over the first 500 amino acids 62% are identical and 90% similar. Overall the sequence identity of NIM-1 to NIMA is 52%, and overall similarity 64.8%. Like NIMA, the NIM-1 kinase domain contains a cysteine residue (amino acid 34) two positions upstream from the putative ATP interactive lysine, in contrast to other protein kinases, which generally have an alanine, and occasionally a valine or an isoleucine, at this position (Fig. 3). The NIMA-related kinases all have an N-terminal kinase domain and a C-terminal extension. However, unlike the majority of other kinases, NIMA has an insert of 22 amino acids in kinase domain VI, as does Kin3 and NIM-1. However, Kin3 also contains a second insert of 38 amino acids in this region that is absent in NIMA and NIM-1 and most other protein kinases. NIM-1 is thus overall most similar to NIMA (Fig. 3). One feature found both in NIM-1 (starting at 306) and Nek2 (starting at 306) is a leucine zipper-like motif. This motif has been implicated in DNA binding and protein-protein interactions (12Landschulz W.H. Johnson P.F. McKnight S.L. Science. 1988; 240: 1759-1764Google Scholar). The significance of this motif in NIM-1 and Nek2 is at present unclear. To test the ability of nim-1 to functionally complement the nimA5 mutation of A. nidulans we transformed it into A. nidulans. Plasmid pUCX7-17 contains nim-1 as a 5.0-kb HindIII-XbaI fragment (Fig. 1b) in pUC18. This fragment contains the open reading frame encoding NIM-1 flanked 5’ and 3’ by about 1.6 and 1.0 kb, respectively. Two control plasmids were also constructed in the same vector (Fig. 1b). Strain SO6 (nimA5 and pyrG89) was transformed with a plasmid containing pyrG (23Oakley B.R. Rinehart J.E. Mitchell B.L. Oakley C.E. Carmona C. Gray G.L. May G.S. Gene (Amst.). 1987; 61: 385-399Google Scholar) alone to complement the pyrG89 mutation or in combination with one of the plasmids described above. After limited growth at the permissive temperature on selective media one-half of the plates were shifted to the restrictive temperature of 42°C. After 2 days of growth (Fig. 1c) only transformants receiving both pyrG and pUCX7-17 were able to form colonies at 42°C. The control plasmids or pyrG alone allowed colony formation at 32°C but not at 42°C. Since one of the control plasmids contains the complete insert, with part being reversed, it indicates that the complementing activity resides in NIM-1 and not another protein encoded by the insert DNA of pUCX7-17. To address the issue of whether nim-1 could functionally complement nimA5 as a single copy gene, rather than as a high copy number suppressor, Southern blot analysis was carried out on DNA isolated from a wild type strain and five transformants co-transformed with pyrG and the full-length nim-1. Duplicate blots were hybridized with DNA probes labeled to an equal specific activity. With the A. nidulans nimA-specific probe all strains generated an equivalent signal, indicating equal loading and transfer to the blot (Fig. 4a). With the N. crassa nim-1 probe wild type DNA showed no hybridization under the high stringency conditions used. Based on the relative intensities of the signal produced, transformants 1, 2, 3, and 5 had a single copy of the N. crassa nim-1 integrated into their genome (Fig. 4a). To establish how well a single copy of N. crassa nim-1 could complement the nimA5 mutation in A. nidulans we grew strains at 32°C (permissive temperature), at 37°C (semi-restrictive temperature), and at 42°C (restrictive temperature). Colony diameters were measured for 5 days, and the final colonies were photographed (Fig. 4b). At 32°C no difference in growth rate could be detected among the control strain, the nimA5-containing strain, and a strain containing nimA5 and a single copy of nim-1. However at 37°C growth of the nimA5 strain was slightly inhibited, and the control strain and nimA5 + nim-1 strain grew at essentially the same rate. At 42°C the nimA5 strain was unable to form a colony, but the wild type and nimA5 strain containing nim-1 could both form a conidiating colony. These data indicate that a single copy of N. crassa nim-1 can complement the nimA5 mutation of A. nidulans for vegetative growth and conidia formation. Unlike all other kinases that we are aware of, both NIMA and NIM-1 have a cysteine −2 from the conserved lysine residue in the ATP binding pocket. This unusual conservation led us to ask if this specific residue (cysteine 38) is important to the function of NIMA in A. nidulans. Three forms of nimA were cloned into the A. nidulans expression vector pAL5 to put their expression under control of the alcA promoter (41Waring R.B. May G.S. Morris N.R. Gene (Amst.). 1989; 79: 119-130Google Scholar; 6Doonan J.H. MacKintosh C. Osmani S. Cohen P. Bai G. Lee E.Y.C. Morris N.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 18889-18894Google Scholar; 42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). These constructs were introduced into a nimA5-containing strain and tested for their ability to replace nimA5 function at the restrictive temperature (Table 1). Both the wild type and C38S versions of nimA were able to complement the nimA5 mutation at 42°C only when the alcA promoter was active due to growth on either glycerol (alcA noninduced nonrepressed) or ethanol (alcA induced). The kinase-negative version of nimA was unable to complement under identical conditions. These data indicate that cysteine 38 is not essential for NIMA function under these test conditions. A similar result was obtained when cysteine 38 was changed to an alanine, the most commonly found amino acid at this location in other protein kinases (data not shown).Tabled 1 Open table in a new tab At 32°C on alcA-inducing media (ethanol) several transformants were unable to form colonies (Table 1). For strains transformed with pAL5B1 and pAL5B1C38S this is most likely due to the presence of multiple copies of the plasmids, since we have previously shown that high expression levels of active NIMA causes premature mitotic induction (32Osmani S.A. Pu R.T. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 53: 237-244Google Scholar), which is lethal. For the kinase-negative construct the inhibition of growth is caused by dominant negative effects as these cells arrest with nuclei in an interphase configuration (data not shown), a result also observed by 18Lu K.P. Kemp B.E. Means A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6603-6607Google Scholar. To define the nimA1, nimA5, and nimA7 mutations at the DNA level we sequenced DNA amplified by polymerase chain reaction from the mutants and a wild type strain. This analysis confirmed the previously published cDNA sequence of nimA (32Osmani S.A. Pu R.T. Morris N.R. Cell. 1988; 53: 237-244Google Scholar) and also identified two introns after positions 491 (64 base pairs) and 544 (53 base pairs). The first is in the same position as the first putative intron of nim-1. For each mutant allele we identified three different point mutations that generated a single amino acid substitution (Table 2).Tabled 1 Open table in a new tab Cells containing nimA1, nimA5, or nimA7 all arrest in G2 when grown or shifted to the restrictive temperature. Since the level of NIMA protein accumulates during G2 and is destroyed upon mitotic progression (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar; 42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar) we considered the possibility that the temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA could cause thermal instability. To test this hypothesis, we arrested cells in G2 by shifting them to the restrictive temperature (42°C). Cells were then released into mitosis by shifting to the permissive temperature. The mitotic index of the cultures and the level of NIMA protein and NIMA kinase activity were determined. Representative data for the nimA1 allele are shown in Fig. 5. One hour after the shift to the restrictive temperature the nimA1 strain had decreased NIMA kinase activity. The activity then recovered by 3 h to a level slightly higher than the preshift levels. Upon return to permissive temperature NIMA kinase activity increased, and cells entered mitosis synchronously. The kinase activity then decreased as cells completed mitosis (Fig. 5). The level of NIMA protein also showed dramatic changes in abundance and phosphorylation state during the transition through G2 and mitosis. At the G2 arrest point of nimA1 NIMA protein accumulated to high levels, but it was only partially active. Upon the return to permissive temperature NIMA protein was hyperphosphorylated, and its mobility decreased during SDS-PAGE (Fig. 5). As cells progressed through mitosis NIMA protein was proteolytically destroyed. Similar results were obtained using the nimA5 and nimA7 alleles (data not shown),2 2X. S. Ye and S. A. Osmani, manuscript in preparation. but these two mutations caused arrest in G2 with much reduced NIMA kinase activity, although all three mutations arrested in G2 with fully activated p34cdc2/cyclin B H1 kinase activity (Fig. 5 and data not shown). These data demonstrate that the temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA do not prevent accumulation of NIMA protein during G2. However, these alleles do prevent the hyperphosphorylation and full activation of NIMA that normally occurs during mitotic initiation. Several classes of serine/threonine-specific protein kinases, including cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (40Steinberg R.A. Cauthron R.D. Symcox M.M. Shuntoh H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 2332-2341Google Scholar), the cyclin-dependent protein kinases (3Booher R. Beach D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1986; 6: 3523-3530Google Scholar), and mitogen-activated protein kinases (33Payne D.M. Rossomando A.J. Martino P. Erickson A.K. Her J.-H. Shabanowitz J. Hunt D.F. Weber M.J. Sturgill T.W. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 885-892Google Scholar), all require phosphorylation in a specific region of their catalytic domains to activate their protein kinase potential. This region, loop L12, which connects protein kinase domains VII and VIII (10Hanks S.K. Quinn A.M. Hunter T. Science. 1988; 241: 42-52Google Scholar), contains several potential phosphorylation sites in NIMA, which are in positions analogous to the phosphorylation sites required for cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase, cyclin-dependent protein kinases, and mitogen-activated protein kinase activation (Fig. 6a). Interestingly, one particular site (Thr199 of NIMA) is conserved among all of the NIMA-related kinases, and phosphorylation of the analogous site in cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase is required for normal cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase activity. We therefore generated four mutant versions of NIMA in which one of the four potential phosphorylation sites was changed to an alanine (S198A, T199A, Y200A, and T203A). These constructs were then expressed in Escherichia coli, and equal amounts of NIMA protein were tested for β-casein kinase activity. Only the T199A mutant form of NIMA had greatly reduced β-casein kinase activity compared with either the wild type or the other mutant forms of NIMA (Fig. 6b). Thus threonine 199 of NIMA is a candidate phosphorylation site required for NIMA β-casein kinase activity. The T199A mutant form of NIMA was not completely inactive as a protein kinase, since it was able to undergo autophosphorylation, as could be observed in the kinase reactions to which β-casein was added (Fig. 6b). In addition, if a peptide substrate was used (16Lu K.P. Means A.R. EMBO. J. 1994; 13: 2103-2113Google Scholar), then significant kinase activity (30% of wild type) could be measured for the T199A form of NIMA. However, the activity of T199A NIMA was not improved by increasing the concentration of either β-casein or ATP. The K40M kinase-negative version of NIMA was still inactive as a kinase using the peptide as substrate, but the S198A and Y200A versions had similar activity to the wild type (data not shown). Since the T199A form of NIMA was not completely inactivated as a kinase we tested its ability to function in A. nidulans. An alcA promoter-driven form of the T199A mutant in the expression vector pAL5 (pAL5B1T199A) was introduced into a nimA5-containing strain and tested for its ability to replace nimA5 function at restrictive temperature. On alcA-inducing media at restrictive temperature no complementation of nimA5 was observed using the T199A construct although wild type alcA driven NIMA was able to complement (Table 1). Thus, Thr199 is not only important for NIMA β-casein kinase activity when expressed in E. coli, it is also essential for NIMA function in Aspergillus. We have isolated a functional homolog of the A. nidulans nimA cell cycle regulator from N. crassa called nim-1, the first such homolog isolated. Over the catalytic domain the two kinases are 75% identical, but their C-terminal extensions are much less similar. Because of the divergence between the nimA homologs from A. nidulans and N. crassa, which are both filamentous members of the Ascomycetes fungi, it is unlikely that higher eukaryotic functional homologs will have highly conserved C-terminal noncatalytic domains. However, there are important functional domains in the C terminus of NIMA, which is essential for function in A. nidulans (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar) and contains three putative bipartite nuclear localization motifs. This motif consists of two basic amino acids followed by a spacer region, which can vary from 10 to 37 amino acids in length, and ends with a cluster of five amino acids containing at least three basic residues (4Dingwall C. Laskey R.A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1991; 16: 478-481Google Scholar). The first such motif in NIMA starts at amino acid 299. A similar motif also occurs at a comparable position in NIM-1, but the second basic clusters do not align, since the NIM-1 spacer is composed of 19 amino acids and the NIMA spacer is composed of 11 amino acids. Nor do the other two nuclear localization motifs of NIMA align with comparable motifs in NIM-1. However, NIM-1 does contain another nuclear localization motif starting at amino acid 633 in a region that is very poorly conserved between the two kinases. Inspection of the other NIMA-related kinases identified at least one putative bipartite nuclear localization motif in Nek1, Nek2, and Stk2 but none in Kin3 or NrkA. This motif is thus common but not universal in the NIMA-related kinases. At present little data is available regarding the subcellular localization of any of these kinases, but given their overall basic nature and the existence of multiple bipartite nuclear localization signals in several of these kinases, a nuclear localization appears likely for at least NIMA, NIM-1, Nek2, Nek1, and Stk2. Indeed, it has recently been shown that NIMA expressed in HeLa cells does localize to the nucleus (15Lu K.P. Hunter T. Cell. 1995; 81: 413-424Google Scholar). Another intriguing motif found in the C terminus of NIMA are PEST sequences, which have been implicated in mediating rapid protein turnover, and such motifs are typically found in proteins that have very short half-lives (35Rogers S. Wells R. Rechsteiner M. Science. 1986; 234: 364-368Google Scholar). Two regions of NIMA gave a score of 12.6 (amino acids 406-437) and 16.4 (amino acids 502-524), and over comparable regions NIM-1 also scored high for PEST motifs, 5.3 (amino acids 393-444) and 11.0 (amino acids 522-543). This indicates that NIMA and NIM-1 may have short half-lives, and we know that removal of the PEST sequences from NIMA generates a very stable kinase that arrests cells in mitosis (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar) and that normally NIMA protein is proteolytically destroyed during mitotic transition (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar and Fig. 5). In light of the mitotic instability of NIMA it is intriguing that it contains a motif, RXXLXXXXN, in protein kinase subdomain III, which is similar to a mitotic cyclin destruction box (9Glotzer M. Murray A.W. Kirschner M.W. Nature. 1991; 349: 132-138Google Scholar). None of the other NIMA-related kinases match at all three conserved positions in this region, but human Nek2 does contain this motif starting at position amino acid 361 and is also degraded during the cell cycle (38Schultz S.J. Fry A.M. Sutterlin C. Ried T. Nigg E.A. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 1-11Google Scholar). Sequence analysis of three different mutant alleles of nimA identified three amino acid substitutions that cause temperature sensitivity to NIMA, and each residue changed is in or near the protein kinase domain. nimA7 has glutamic acid 41 changed to a glycine, and the NIMA-related kinases NIM-1, Nek1, and Nek2 all contain a glutamic acid at the equivalent position. Lysine 40, which is adjacent to glutamic acid 41, has been implicated in ATP binding in protein kinases. This mutation may therefore interfere with the ability of NIMA to bind ATP correctly at the restrictive temperature. nimA5 changes tyrosine 91 to an asparagine, and NIM-1, Kin3, Nek1, and Nek2 also have a tyrosine at this position. This region is clearly conserved among the NIMA-like protein kinases, and it has been suggested that a conserved motif, based on this region of homology, may be a characteristic of NIMA-like protein kinases (38Schultz S.J. Fry A.M. Sutterlin C. Ried T. Nigg E.A. Cell Growth & Differ. 1994; 5: 1-11Google Scholar). The nimA1 mutation is located at the border of the kinase domain and changes leucine 304 to a proline. This mutation is the weakest of the three, and cells arrested at restrictive temperature containing this allele still retain some protein kinase activity. The three temperature-sensitive alleles of nimA arrested cells in G2 with elevated NIMA protein levels. These mutations do not therefore affect the expression of the mutant proteins but instead render them functionally inactive at restrictive temperature. The accumulated proteins were not hyperphosphorylated in G2 but were rapidly phosphorylated upon release into mitosis. This hyperphosphorylation is normally seen after activation of p34cdc2 during mitotic initiation (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). Since each of the nimA alleles causes G2 arrest with fully activated p34cdc2/cyclin B H1 kinase activity it is unclear why NIMA is not hyperphosphorylated by p34cdc2/cyclin B at the G2 arrest point. One possibility is that at the G2 arrest points of nimA1, nimA5, and nimA7 the NIMA protein has not assumed a conformation that is a suitable substrate for p34cdc2/cyclin B. Upon release to permissive temperature, NIMA would be able to assume an active configuration and then become a substrate for p34cdc2/cyclin B. Alternatively, if NIMA and p34cdc2 are in different subcellular compartments prior to initiation of mitosis, activation of NIMA may allow the active p34cdc2/cyclin B kinase access to NIMA within the cell, which it could then phosphorylate. Comparison of published protein kinase sequences similar to NIMA and NIM-1 identified a conserved potential phosphorylation site (Thr199 in NIMA) analogous to the activating site autophosphorylated in cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase. Mutation of Thr199 specifically affected NIMA kinase activity when expressed in E. coli, although other mutations in the same region had no effect. Thus, like cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase, the NIMA family of protein kinases may require (auto?)phosphorylation at Thr199 for normal protein kinase activity. Although severely compromised as a β-casein kinase the T199A mutant still retained the ability to undergo autophosphorylation and partially retained the ability to phosphorylate a NIMA-specific peptide substrate. The equivalent mutant form of cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (in which ThrT197 of cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase is also changed to an alanine) is also not completely inactive as a protein kinase but has greatly increased Km values for both the ATP and protein substrates (40Steinberg R.A. Cauthron R.D. Symcox M.M. Shuntoh H. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 2332-2341Google Scholar). Thus mutation of this site in cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase and NIMA has similar effects on their kinase activities, since both kinases are compromised by this mutation but neither is completely inactivated by it. However, the T199A mutant form of NIMA, although still partially active as a protein kinase, was found to be functionally inactive, demonstrating the importance of this particular residue. If NIMA is normally activated by phosphorylation of Thr199, then NIMA is able to autophosphorylate at this position when expressed in E. coli. Thr199, and its equivalent in NIM-1, Kin3, and Nek2, is found within a region that corresponds to the NIMA phosphorylation consensus sequence FXXT (16Lu K.P. Means A.R. EMBO. J. 1994; 13: 2103-2113Google Scholar), further supporting the notion that NIMA autophosphorylates at this site. NIMA is known to undergo autophosphorylation on multiple sites when expressed in E. coli (17Lu K.P. Osmani S.A. Means A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8769-8776Google Scholar), and mapping studies will have to be carried out to determine if NIMA does in fact phosphorylate Thr199 when expressed in E. coli. We know that NIMA is phosphorylated during G2 to yield an active protein kinase in A. nidulans and that it is then further phosphorylated during mitotic initiation after activation of the p34cdc2/cyclin B protein kinase (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). As the nimA1, nimA5, and nimA7 alleles all arrest in G2 with elevated levels of NIMA protein, which is largely inactive, these mutations may prevent autophosphorylation of NIMA at threonine 199. Testing this possibility will require mapping of the phosphorylation sites of NIMA during cell cycle progression. This task is likely to be difficult since, based on molecular weight shifts seen during SDS-PAGE, the NIMA protein is phosphorylated at multiple sites during the cell cycle (42Ye X.S. Xu G. Pu R.T. Fincher R.R. McGuire S.L. Osmani A.H. Osmani S.A. EMBO. J. 1995; 14: 986-994Google Scholar). Several questions remain. Are any of the other NIMA-related protein kinases functional homologs of A. nidulans nimA? In addition, if Thr199 is phosphorylated in vivo, does the NIMA family of kinases require autophosphorylation of Thr199 for function, or is there a NIMA-activating kinase? We are most thankful to Liz Cigelnik for excellent technical assistance.

Expression of the Wilms' tumor gene WT1 is tightly regulated throughout development. In constrast, the WT1 promoter is promiscuous, functioning in all cell lines tested. We have cloned a transcriptional silencer that is involved in regulation of the WT1 gene. The transcriptional silencer is located in the third intron of the WT1 gene, approximately 12 kilobases from the promoter, and functions to repress transcription from the WT1 promoter in cell lines of non-renal origin. The 460-base pair silencer region is unusual in that it contains a full-length Alu repeat. We have also cloned an enhancer like-element located 1.3 kilobases upstream of the WT1 promoter. Expression of the Wilms' tumor gene WT1 is tightly regulated throughout development. In constrast, the WT1 promoter is promiscuous, functioning in all cell lines tested. We have cloned a transcriptional silencer that is involved in regulation of the WT1 gene. The transcriptional silencer is located in the third intron of the WT1 gene, approximately 12 kilobases from the promoter, and functions to repress transcription from the WT1 promoter in cell lines of non-renal origin. The 460-base pair silencer region is unusual in that it contains a full-length Alu repeat. We have also cloned an enhancer like-element located 1.3 kilobases upstream of the WT1 promoter. Wilms' tumor is an embryonal tumor of the kidney affecting 1 in 10,000 live births worldwide(1Young Jr., J.L. Miller R.W. J. Pediatr. 1975; 86: 254-258Google Scholar). Wilms' tumor has a number of genes associated with its pathogenesis, but only the WT1 gene, associated with the WAGR syndrome (Wilms' tumor, aniridia, genito-urinary abnormalities, and mental retardation)(2Riccardi V.M. Sujansky E. Smith A.C. Francke U. Pediatrics. 1978; 61: 604-610Google Scholar), has been cloned. Other genes purported to be involved in Wilms' tumor pathogenesis include a gene (WT2) at 11p15 associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (3Huff V. Saunders G.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1155: 295-306Google Scholar) and a gene associated with familial Wilms' tumor(3Huff V. Saunders G.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1155: 295-306Google Scholar). The human WT1 gene maps to chromosomal band 11p13 and encodes a zinc finger transcription factor(4Call K.M. Glaser T. Ito C.Y. Buckler A.J. Pelletier J. Haber D.A. Rose E.A. Kral A. Yeger H. Lewis W.H. Jones C. Housman D.E. Cell. 1990; 60: 509-520Google Scholar, 5Gessler M. Poustka A. Cavenee W. Neve R.L. Orkin S.H. Bruns G.A.P. Nature. 1990; 343: 774-778Google Scholar). The WT1 protein contains a proline-rich amino-terminal region that mediates transcriptional repression and has four Cys-Cys, His-His zinc fingers in the carboxyl terminus (exons 7-10) that bind DNA (Fig. 1A)(3Huff V. Saunders G.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1155: 295-306Google Scholar). WT1 binds a consensus sequence of GNGNGGGNG (6Paveletich N.P. Pabo C.O. Science. 1991; 252: 809-817Google Scholar) and represses transcription from the promoters of the early growth response gene 1 (EGR1)(7Madden S.L. Cook D.M. Morris J.F. Gashler A. Sukhatme V.P. Rauscher III, F.J. Science. 1991; 253: 1550-1553Google Scholar), platelet-derived growth factor a-chain (PDGF a-chain)(8Wang Z.Y. Madden S.L. Deuel T.F. Rauscher III, F.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21999-22002Google Scholar), insulin-like growth factor II (IGF II)(9Drummond I.A. Madden S.L. Rohwer-Nutter P. Bell G.I. Sukhatme V.P. Rauscher F.J. III Science. 1992; 257: 674-678Google Scholar), insulin-like growth factor I receptor (IGF1R)(10Werner H. Rauscher III, F.J. Sukhatme V.P. Drummond I.A. Roberts C.T. LeRoith D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 12577-12582Google Scholar), transforming growth factor β 1 (TGFβ1)(11Dey B.R. Sukhatme V.P. Roberts A.B. Sporn M.B. Rauscher III, F.J. Kim S.-J. Mol. Endocrinol. 1994; 8: 595-602Google Scholar), colony-stimulating factor 1 (CSF-1) (12Harrington M.A. Konicek B. Song A. Xia Z.-L. Fredricks W.J. Rauscher III, F.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 21271-21275Google Scholar) genes and can repress its own promoter (13Rupprecht H.D. Drummond I.A. Madden S.L. Rauscher III, F.J. Sukhatme V.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6198-6206Google Scholar) in CAT reporter assays. In previous work we have characterized the WT1 promoter region(14Fraizer G.C. Wu Y.-J. Hewitt S.M. Maity T. Ton C.C.T. Huff V. Saunders G.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8892-8900Google Scholar). The human WT1 promoter consists of a 652-bp GC-rich region containing multiple transcription start sites. The promoter functions in a promiscuous fashion, with transcription detectable in all cell lines tested by transient CAT reporter assays.
