In sum, the data are consistent with a role for a myristoylated amino terminus in membrane association, although with the more recent recognition that several Gα subunits are also palmitoylated, the contribution of the less hydrophobic myristate may need to be reassessed(33Mumby S.M. Kleuss C. Gilman A.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 2800-2804Google Scholar). Integral membrane proteins have been identified and purified based on their phase-partitioning characteristics(34Bordier C. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 1604-1607Google Scholar). Solutions of Triton X-114 separate into detergent-rich and detergent-depleted (aqueous) phases at ≈30°C. It is generally agreed upon that the more “hydrophobic” a protein or peptide, the more likely it will partition into the detergent-rich phase. This partitioning difference has been the basis for separating integral from peripheral membrane proteins(34Bordier C. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 1604-1607Google Scholar). We investigated this partitioning procedure as a new way of characterizing the hydrophobic and membrane-association domains of native and recombinant Gtα and myristoylated and nonmyristoylated rGoα as well as possibly assessing protein-protein interactions in a purified defined system. Gpp(NH)p, GTP, and GTPβγS were purchased from Boehringer Mannheim; [32P]NAD (30 Ci/mmol), [35S]GTPβγS (40 Ci/mmol), [3H]GTP (15 Ci/mmol), [3H]myristic acid (16 Ci/mmol), GA/1 antibody, and AS/7 antibody from DuPont NEN; Triton X-114 from Fluka; TPCK-treated trypsin from Worthington; glutathione-agarose, NAD, ATP, and soybean trypsin inhibitor from Sigma; blue Sepharose CL-6B and PD-10 columns from Pharmacia Biochem Inc.; Triton X-100 from Research Products International Corp.; isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactopyranoside from United States Biochemical Corp.; goat anti-rabbit IgG horseradish peroxidase-coupled antibody from Pierce; goat anti-mouse IgG horseradish peroxidase-coupled antibody from Promega; LB medium from Digene; ampicillin sodium from Amresco; and molecular weight standards from Life Technologies, Inc. Densitometry was performed with a Molecular Dynamics laser densitometer and Image Quant software. SDS-PAGE and Western blotting were done in a Novex Minicell apparatus using 12% or 4-20% gradient Tris/glycine gels. PDE was essentially prepared as described previously(35Baehr W. Devlin M.J. Applebury M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 11669-11677Google Scholar, 36Hurley J.B. Stryer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 11094-11099Google Scholar). Briefly, fresh bovine eyes were obtained from a local abattoir; retinas were dissected, frozen on dry ice, and stored at −70°C. After thawing, retinas were suspended in buffer A (60 mM KCl, 30 mM NaCl, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.5, 1 mM NaN3, 2 mM MgCl2, 0.1 mM EGTA) containing 45% sucrose, vortexed, and centrifuged (27,750 × g, 20 min). After diluting the supernatant with an equal volume of buffer A without sucrose, rod outer segments (ROS) were pelleted by centrifugation (27,750 × g, 20 min). Pellets were washed twice by suspending in buffer A and centrifuging (27,750 × g, 20 min). Washed ROS were then suspended in buffer B (5 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.05 mM EGTA, 0.5 mM NaN3, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 1 μg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor, 1 μg/ml leupeptin) and centrifuged (45,000 × g, 30 min). This supernatant, which contained mainly PDE (35Baehr W. Devlin M.J. Applebury M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 11669-11677Google Scholar) and arrestin, was concentrated in a Macrosep 100 concentrator (Filtron Technology Corp.) and used as such or further purified by molecular sizing on an Ultrogel AcA-34 column. ROS, after extraction of PDE, were washed three additional times by centrifugation in buffer B without soybean trypsin inhibitor or leupeptin (45,000 × g, 30 min). Transducin was then eluted with buffer B containing 100 μM GTP with centrifugation (45,000 × g, 30 min). Gtα and Gtβγ subunits were resolved by blue Sepharose chromatography(39Shinozawa T. Uchida S. Martin E. Cafiso D. Hubbell W. Bitensky M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1980; 77: 1408-1411Google Scholar). To prepare Gtα with radiolabeled GDP or GTP, PDE-depleted ROS were washed three times in buffer A, and Gtα was eluted by two extractions with buffer A containing 50 μM [35S]GTPβγS (2-5 mCi/mmol) or 100 μM [3H]GTP (4-10 mCi/mmol)(38Khn H. Nature. 1980; 283: 587-589Google Scholar). Gtα was concentrated with a Centriprep-10 (Amicon, Inc.), and free nucleotide was removed using PD-10 columns. Samples were stored at 4°C and used within 3 days. Bound nucleotide was identified by heating Gtα at 95°C and analyzing the released nucleotide on polyethyleneimine-cellulose TLC plates developed with 1.6 M LiCl(40Randerath K. Randerath E. Methods Enzymol. 1967; 12: 323-347Google Scholar), which verified that Gtα eluted with [35S]GTPβγS retained this nucleotide. [3H]GTP bound to Gtα was, however, hydrolyzed to [3H]GDP. To obtain Gtαβγ in GDP-bound (Gtαβγ•GDP) and GTPβγS-bound (Gtαβγ•GTPβγS) states, procedures were identical except that hypotonic conditions were used for elution with labeled nucleotide(38Khn H. Nature. 1980; 283: 587-589Google Scholar). Rhodopsin was prepared by the method of Hong and Hubbell(41Hong K. Hubbell W.L. Biochemistry. 1973; 12: 4517-4523Google Scholar). Protein concentrations were determined by Coomassie Blue assay (Bio-Rad) using bovine serum albumin as a standard. PDE activity was assayed for 10 min at 30°C in 0.3 ml of 50 mM HEPES, pH 7.5, 0.1 mM EGTA, 8.3 mM MgCl2, 1 μM [3H]cGMP (~20,000 cpm/assay). Reactions were terminated by addition of 100 μl of 11.25 mM cGMP and 5 mM 5′-GMP in 250 mM HCl; neutralized with 100 μl of 250 mM NaOH in 250 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0; and then incubated with 5′-nucleotidase (Crotalus atrox venom) at 30°C for 20 min. The 3H-labeled nucleoside produced was collected for radioassay(42Yamamoto T. Manganiello V.C. Vaughan M. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 12526-12533Google Scholar). In a modification of the method of Bordier(34Bordier C. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 1604-1607Google Scholar), Triton X-114 was added (final concentration of 1%) to protein samples in buffer C (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.05 mM EGTA, 0.5 mM NaN3, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 150 mM NaCl) in a final volume of 40-75 μl. Mixtures were gently mixed and kept on ice for 3-5 min. After warming to 37°C for 5 min, the cloudy solution was centrifuged (300 × g, 5 min) in a swinging bucket rotor prewarmed to 30-37°C. The upper aqueous layer was aspirated. Buffer C was added to the detergent phase, which contained no visible particulates, and Triton X-114 was added to the aqueous phase to equalize the compositions and volumes of the two fractions. Equal volumes of each phase were subjected to SDS-PAGE. Proteins were stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue and quantified by densitometry. In experiments in which Gtα contained radiolabeled nucleotide, samples of the two phases were subjected to PD-10 column chromatography to separate unbound from protein-bound nucleotide, which was quantified by liquid scintillation counting. Nucleotide that became unbound during partitioning accumulated primarily (>85%) in the aqueous phase. Transducin (Gtαβγ; 0.5 mg/ml), Gtα (0.2 mg/ml), or PDE (1 mg/ml) in hypotonic buffer was incubated with TPCK-treated trypsin (1.2 μg/ml) at 30°C for 2-10 min. Reactions were stopped by adding phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride or soybean trypsin inhibitor (final concentrations of 1 mM and 0.1 mg/ml, respectively). DNA inserts for Gtα and a carboxyl-truncated form of Gtα were prepared by polymerase chain reaction using Gtα1 cDNA as template. The 5′-primer for both transducin molecules was 5′-GCAGCAGCATGATCAGGGGCCAGCGCTGAGGAGAAG-3′, which includes a BclI restriction site enabling excision of the polymerase chain reaction product with BclI and cloning into the BamHI site of the pGEX-2T vector (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) without cleaving the BamHI site within the Gtα1 coding sequence. The 3′-primers (5′-GCGCCACGGGAATTCTCAGAAGAGCCCGCAGTCTT-3′ and 5′-GCGCCAGCGGAATTCTCAAAACTTGACGTTCTGCGTGTC-3′) included an EcoRI site after the natural stop codon or after a stop codon introduced to replace codon 331 (valine) to yield a truncated protein. Following polymerase chain reaction, Taq polymerase (Perkin Elmer) and unincorporated nucleotides were removed using a QIAGEN polymerase chain reaction purification kit. Products were digested with BclI and EcoRI. Gtα inserts were gel-purified with Qiaex resin (QIAGEN) and ligated into the BamHI/EcoRI-restricted pGEX-2T vector using T4 DNA ligase. Escherichia coli DH5α competent cells (Life Technologies, Inc.) were transformed using heat shock and selected on ampicillin-containing LB agar plates. After isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactopyranoside induction, positive clones were screened for protein production using SDS-PAGE. For large-scale purification of fusion proteins, E. coli cells were grown in 500-1000 ml of LB/ampicillin medium at 37°C to an absorbance of 0.4 at 600 nm. Isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactopyranoside was added (final concentration of 100 μM), and incubation (with shaking) was continued for 3-4 h. After centrifugation, cell pellets were washed once with phosphate-buffered saline, suspended in 10 ml of phosphate-buffered saline, and lysed using nitrogen cavitation. Sarcosine (0.5%) was added to solubilize the fusion proteins, and cell debris was removed by centrifugation (15,000 × g, 4°C, 10 min). Triton X-100 (final concentration of 1%) and glutathione-agarose beads were added to the supernatant, and the mixture was rocked for 2-3 h at 4°C. Binding of fusion protein to the beads in the presence of sarcosine required Triton X-100. Bound fusion protein (0.25-1.0 mg) was eluted with 3-5 ml of 10 mM reduced glutathione, 200 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 0.5% Triton X-100 and cleaved with thrombin (2-4 μg/ml). Intact Gtα was quantified by immunoblot using AS/7, a polyclonal antipeptide antibody directed against the carboxyl terminus of Gtα(43Cerione R.A. Kroll S. Rajaram R. Unson C. Goldsmith P. Spiegel A.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 9345-9352Google Scholar). GA/1, an amino terminus-directed G protein-specific polyclonal antibody, reacted similarly with intact and carboxyl-truncated forms of recombinant Gtα. Intact Gtα was ADP-ribosylated by pertussis toxin; as expected, the truncated form, which lacks the ADP-ribose acceptor site (Cys-347), was not. The coding region of bovine Goα cDNA was inserted into the pT7/Nde expression vector(44Hong J.-X. Haun R.S. Tsai S.-C. Moss J. Vaughan M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 9743-9745Google Scholar). This was transfected into E. coli BL21(DE3) cells (Novagen), which had or had not been previously transfected with the pACYC177/ET3d/yNMT vector(45Haun R.S. Tsai S.-C. Adamik R. Moss J. Vaughan M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 7064-7068Google Scholar). Bacteria cotransfected with both plasmids overexpressed the yeast N-myristoyltransferase and Goα, with the resultant production of myristoylated rGoα(46Duronio R.J. Jackson-Mchelski E. Heuckeroth R.O. Olins P.O. Devine C.S. Yonemoto W. Slice L.W. Taylor S.S. Gordon J.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 1506-1510Google Scholar), whereas those transfected only with pT7/Nde containing Goα sequence overexpressed nonmyristoylated rGoα. An overnight culture (0.2 ml) of the cotransfected bacteria was added to 2 ml of LB medium containing the appropriate antibiotics, grown at 37°C for 1 h, and induced with 0.2 mM isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactopyranoside in the presence of [3H]myristic acid (100 μCi, 16 Ci/mmol). Growth was continued for an additional 3 h before centrifugation (15,000 × g, 7 min). Cells were then resuspended in phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.4; lysed by sonification; and centrifuged (15,000 × g, 45 min). The supernatant, which contained crude 3H-labeled myristoylated rGoα, was used in phase-partitioning experiments. The same procedure was used for the singly transfected cells, which produced nonmyristoylated rGoα. Following partitioning, proteins were detected by autoradiography in experiments using 3H-labeled myristoylated rGoα and with an anti-Goα antibody (47Tsai S.-C. Adamik R. Kanaho Y. Halpern J.L. Moss J. Biochemistry. 1987; 26: 4728-4737Google Scholar) after blotting to nitrocellulose for both 3H-labeled myristoylated rGoα and nonmyristoylated rGoα. Gtα (1 μg) with or without the indicated amounts of Gtβγ was incubated at 30°C for 20 min (total volume of 50 μl), in 50 mM potassium phosphate, pH 7.5, 10 mM thymidine, 10 μM [32P]NAD (1 μCi/assay), 40 μM ATP with 0.1 μg of pertussis toxin-activated with 20 mM dithiothreitol immediately before use(13Hsia J.A. Moss J. Hewlett E.L. Vaughan M. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 1086-1090Google Scholar). [32P]ADP-ribosylated proteins were subjected to Triton X-114 phase partitioning, separated by SDS-PAGE, and exposed to Kodak XAR film at −70°C for 1-4 h. Gtα (45 μg) was incubated at 30°C for 45 min with or without the NAD:arginine ADP-ribosyltransferase (4.5 μg), which had been purified from turkey erythrocytes (48Moss J. Stanley S.J. Watkins P.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 5838-5840Google Scholar) in 200 μl of buffer containing 50 mM KPO4, pH 7.5, 200 mM NaCl, 100 μM NAD (10-15 μCi). Following labeling, samples were applied to NAP-5 columns (Pharmacia Biotech Inc.) to separate protein-bound from unbound radioactivity (enabling an estimation of extent of labeling) before use in phase-partitioning experiments. Arrestin, a soluble 48-kDa protein that copurified with Gt, remained primarily in the detergent-depleted phase (Fig. 1A and Table 1), whereas Gtβγ (which contains farnesylated Gtγ) and PDE (the β subunit of which is prenylated) (49Anant J.S. Ong O.C. Xie H. Clarke S. O'Brien P.J. Fung B.K.-K. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 687-690Google Scholar) were found mainly in the detergent-rich phase (Fig. 1A and Table 1). Rhodopsin, an integral membrane protein, partitioned, as expected, almost exclusively into the detergent-rich phase (Fig. 1B and Table 1).TABLE I Open table in a new tab Gtα, in the absence of Gtβγ, partitioned about equally between the detergent-rich and detergent-depleted phases (Fig. 1A and Table 1). On repeated partitioning of Gtβγ from either the aqueous or detergent phase, distribution between detergent and aqueous phases was similar regardless of the phase from which Gtα originated (data not shown). In the presence of Gtβγ, Gtα was recovered to a greater extent in the detergent-rich phase. Recovery of Gtα in the detergent-rich phase increased with increasing amounts of Gtβγ (Fig. 2, A and B). In contrast, Gtα appeared not to affect the partitioning of Gtβγ (Table 1). After addition of Gpp(NH)p in the presence of Gtβγ and rhodopsin, Gtα was recovered to a greater extent in the aqueous phase presumably as a result of dissociation of Gtα•Gpp(NH)p from Gtβγ (Fig. 3). In the absence of rhodopsin, Gpp(NH)p had no effect on the partitioning of Gtα (data not shown). Rhodopsin, in the absence of Gtβγ, did not significantly influence the phase partitioning of Gtα (data not shown), consistent with other evidence that Gtβγ is important for functional association of Gtα and receptor(5Phillips W.J. Wong S.C. Cerione R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17040-17046Google Scholar). To evaluate directly the role of bound nucleotide in apparent hydrophobicity, samples of Gtα•GDP, Gtα•GTPβγS, Gtαβγ•GDP, and Gtαβγ•GTPβγS underwent phase partitioning. PD-10 columns were used to separate protein-bound from unbound nucleotide. Ratios of protein-bound nucleotide in aqueous and detergent phases concurred with ratios of total protein on Coomassie Blue-stained SDS-polyacrylamide gels quantified by densitometry (Table 2), indicating that the total protein reflected the fraction containing bound nucleotide, i.e. Gtα retained nucleotide during partitioning. Whether GTPβγS or GDP was bound made no difference to the overall hydrophobicity of Gtα in the absence of Gtβγ (Fig. 4A and Table 2). In the presence of Gtβγ, however, Gtα•GDP was recovered to a much greater extent in the detergent phase, likely as a result of its tight association with the more hydrophobic Gtβγ complex containing the farnesylated βγ subunit. In contrast, Gtα•GTPβγS partitioning was independent of Gtβγ (Fig. 4B and Table 2).TABLE II Open table in a new tab Interaction between the PDE complex and Gtα•GTPβγS was studied by partitioning the proteins separately and together, which yielded similar results whether the amounts of Gtα and PDE were equimolar or one or the other was in excess (data not shown). To verify that the proteins were not denatured during partitioning, PDE activity and Gtα•GTPβγS-activated PDE activity were determined. The distribution of PDE activity in detergent and aqueous phases was similar whether or not Gtα•GTPβγS was present during partitioning (Fig. 5) and also when PDE partitioned in the absence of Gtα•GTPβγS was assayed in its presence (data not shown). The partitioning of Gtα•GTPβγS was not affected by PDE whether measured by SDS-PAGE and densitometry or by quantifying protein-bound radioactive nucleotide (data not shown). To define better the structural domains responsible for partitioning, Gtα, Gtβγ, and Gtαβγ were subjected to limited proteolysis with trypsin. Cleavage products of Gtβγ were recovered in the detergent-rich phase to a greater extent than were those from Gtα (Fig. 6). In the presence of Gtβγ, the fraction of intact 39-kDa Gtα recovered in that phase was greater than that of the 37-kDa fragment lacking the amino terminus (Fig. 6). Since the amino terminus of Gtα is involved in interaction with Gtβγ, it was unclear whether the difference in behavior of intact Gtα and the 37-kDa protein resulted from disruption of the Gtβγ-binding site with loss of ability of Gtα to associate with and be influenced by Gtβγ or whether the amino terminus itself contributed significantly to the hydrophobicity of Gtα. To evaluate this, Gtα was trypsinized without Gtβγ, and in some experiments, after stopping trypsinolysis with phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride or soybean trypsin inhibitor, intact Gtα was added back before partitioning to ensure that sufficient intact Gtα would be recovered for densitometric measurement. Even in the absence of Gtβγ, intact Gtα was recovered to a greater extent in the detergent-rich phase than was the 37-kDa fragment (and other major tryptic products), although amounts of both were less than when Gtβγ was present (Fig. 7; data not shown), consistent with the conclusion that the amino terminus is primarily responsible for the hydrophobic nature of Gtα and that this hydrophobicity is not a consequence solely of interaction with Gtβγ. After trypsinolysis, PDE accumulated mostly in the detergent-depleted phase (Table 1).Figure 7:Phase partitioning of tryptic fragments of Gtα.
